docTitle.titlePart: COMPOSTAJE DE RESIDUOS ORGANICOS MEZCLADOS CON ROCA FOSFORICA

byline.affiliation: Universidad de Los Andes Núcleo "Rafael Rangel"

front.div:
ABSTRACT
In order to evaluate composting parameters and phosphorus availability of natural phosphate by decomposing organic wastes, four composts were prepared using
coffee hulls and pulp, (Gliriscida sepium) leaves and branchs, cattle manure and rock phosphate. The wastes were disposed in piles which were turned and watered
frequently to improve aerobic bioconversion of organic matter. Temperature, pH, electric conductivity and organic matter were evaluated during the composting
period. Ratio N-NH 4
+ / N-NO 3
-and C/N, phosphorus availability were quantified at 112 days in the maturation phase. The maximum temperatures (60 -65
o C) were
observed 15 days after formed the piles. After 60 days the temperatures did not rise beyond 40
o C even close to the turning of materials which indicates the end of the
thermophilic phase. The pH decreases toward the final of decomposition process, regardless tipes of residues. Rock phosphate increases electric conductivity of the
mixtures with coffee pulp but it decreases in the G. sepium one. At 112 days the substrates with coffee pulp shows pH values (7.9 -8.1) and electric conductivity (2.5
-2.9 mS/cm) which were higher statistically than these of G. sepium (7.4 -7.5) and (1.8 -2.3 mS/cm) respectively. In the other hand the organic matter percent in
coffee pulp composts (25.2 -31.1) were lower that G. sepium (30.6 -35.7). It was not posible to determine a clear trend of the organic matter content during the
decomposition period. At 112 days, N-NH 4
+ / N-NO 3
-ratio (0.15 -1.2) indicates different maturation grades of the composts, the lowest C/N ratio (7 -9.1) is
